column2: This war, this opportunity to prove my mettle in combat, has opened my eyes to my true potential as a warrior. My personal combat skills are improving...
column6: En esta guerra he tenido ocasión de probarme en combate y he descubierto mi auténtico potencial. Mi habilidad marcial está mejorando...

column2: May [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodNameCap] guide my heart, hand, and steel.
column6: Que [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodNameCap] guíe mi corazón, mi mano y mi acero.

column2: §Y[Root.GetTitledFirstName]§! begins advancement of [Root.GetHerHis] personal combat skills...\n
column6: §Y[Root.GetTitledFirstName]§! comienza a mejorar su habilidad marcial...\n

column2: I've learned many lessons from this battle. Aside from application of the theoretical tactics my mentors taught me as a boy, I've learned to deftly isolate an opponent in the thick of the front, bring all my focus and concentration to bear upon him, and then, within but a few rounds of melee, swiftly execute him. I'm proud of my clear progression into a greater warrior.
column6: Aprendí mucho de esta batalla. Aparte de la aplicación de las tácticas que me enseñaron mis mentores, he aprendido a aislar a mi oponente en el fragor de la batalla, poner toda mi atención y concentración en abatirle y al fin, con golpes certeros acabar con él. Estoy orgulloso de mi progreso como gran guerrero.

column2: Still, I've more lessons to learn.
§Y[Root.GetTitledFirstName]§! continues advancement of [Root.GetHerHis] personal combat skills...\n
column6: §Y[Root.GetTitledFirstName]§! continúa el avance en su habilidad marcial\n

column2: I will remember this battle in its finest detail until the end of my days. [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodNameCap] guided my sword into the hearts of a countless number of my foes, raising cheers and battle-cries from my surrounding men as I cut a path through the enemy. My mastery of personal combat has come a long way. Apparently, I am not the only one to think so.
column6: Recordaré hasta el más mínimo detalle de esta batalla hasta el final de mis días. [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodNameCap] guió mi espada hasta el corazón de mis enemigos, alzando vítores y gritos de batalla entre mis hombres mientras abría paso con mi espada. Mi maestría en combate no tiene parangón. Aparentemente, no soy el único que lo piensa.

column2: I'm now recognized as a trained fighter.
column6: Ahora se me reconoce como luchador.

column2: I'm now reknowned as skilled fighter.
column6: Ahora soy un luchador de renombre.

column2: I now command the respect of an elite warrior.
column6: Ahora se me respeta como guerrero de élite.

column2: My combat victory against [FromFrom.GetTitledFirstName] was an insightful challenge to my own tactics. [FromFrom.GetSheHeCap] moved differently than I've come to expect and demonstrated a new, effective combat style to me. At no point was my victory certain, but I learned from [FromFrom.GetObjectPronoun] and finally defeated [FromFrom.GetObjectPronoun]. Certainly, I'm now a finer warrior.
column6: Mi victoria sobre [FromFrom.GetTitledFirstName] ha sido un desafío a mis tácticas. [FromFrom.GetSheHeCap] me sorprendió con nuevos movimientos y un estilo de combate eficaz. En ningún momento estuve seguro de ganar, pero aprendí de [FromFrom.GetObjectPronoun] y conseguí derrotarle. Ahora soy un guerrero más diestro.

column2: I'm recognized as a warrior in my own right now.
column6: Ahora soy reconocido como guerrero por derecho propio.

column2: I'm now recognized as a trained fighter.
column6: Ahora se me reconoce como luchador.

column2: I'm now reknowned as skilled fighter.
column6: Ahora soy un luchador de renombre.

column2: I now command the respect of an elite warrior.
column6: Ahora se me respeta como guerrero de élite.

Hmm... ahora es un luchador torpe.

column2: [This.GetTitledFirstName] has no education in the art of personal combat and wants to change that through combat experience.
column6: [This.GetTitledFirstName] no ha sido educado en las artes marciales y quiere cambiar las cosas ganando experiencia en combate.

column2: [This.GetTitledFirstName] has a meager education in the art of personal combat and wants to change that through combat experience.
column6: [This.GetTitledFirstName] tiene escasa formación en las artes marciales y quiere mejorar ganando experiencia en combate.

column2: While [This.GetTitledFirstName] is already well-trained in personal combat, [This.GetSheHe]'d like to take [This.GetHerHis] skills to the next level through experience in the field.
column6: Aunque [This.GetTitledFirstName] está bien entrenado en las artes marciales, le gustaría alcanzar más nivel ganando experiencia en combate.

column2: While many already consider [This.GetTitledFirstName] to be one of the more skilled fighters in the realm, [This.GetSheHe] desires true mastery of [This.GetHerHis] art, and no better way to attain such heights exists than through experience in the field.
column6: Aunque muchos consideran a [This.GetTitledFirstName] uno de los mejores luchadores del reino, a [This.GetSheHe] le gustaría llegar a ser un maestro en el arte de la guerra, y qué mejor modo que ganando experiencia en combate.

Recruit landless warriors into an elite band of brothers that will defend their fellow Gaels.

You have decided to found the Sons of Gwydion, a sacred order of warriors loyal only to the Druids and their Circle, dressed in wolf skins over mail and venerating the famed trickster Gwydion.\n\nThis new Order will not only form a powerful shock force against britain's many enemies, but will also channel the fiery spirits of the younger, restless sons of [Root.GetTitle].

[From.GetFirstName], the great king of the Celts, is distraught over the ravages braught over by our landless sons. Knowing well their need for battle, he has decided to form a sacred band of brothers consisting solely of celtic warriors.\n\nThose who serve him and the Druids are generously rewarded, and even now many of our young men, eager for riches and adventure, have departed for his court to pick up honor Gwydion's old name.
column3: [From.GetFirstName], le grand roi des Grecs, est angoissé par le peu de courage de ses compatriotes. Connaissant bien notre aptitude au combat, il a décidé de composer son équipe de gardes du corps uniquement de guerriers nordiques.\n\nCeux qui le servent dans la grande cité de Miklagård sont généreusement récompensés et, aujourd'hui encore, les jeunes hommes avides de richesse et d'aventure quittent pour la Grèce afin de le servir.
column4: [From.GetFirstName], der große König der Griechen, ist bestürzt über den lausigen Eifer seiner Landsmänner. Euren Kampfesmut kennend, hat er beschlossen, eine Leibwache nur aus nordischen Kriegern aufzustellen.\n\nWer ihm in Miklagard dient, wird reich belohnt und viele Eurer jungen Männer, erpicht auf Gold und Abenteuer, sind nach Griechenland abgereist, um in seinen Dienst zu treten.
column6: [From.GetFirstName], el gran rey de los Griegos, está perturbado por el poco ánimo de sus compatriotas. Conociendo bien nuestra habilidad en la batalla, ha decidido formar una guardia que consiste únicamente de guerreros Nórdicos.\n\nAquellos que le sirven en la gran ciudad de Miklagård son generosamente recompensados, e incluso ahora muchos de nuestros jóvenes, ávidos de riquezas y aventura, han partido hacia Grecia para levantar su estandarte.

column2: May they find the excitement they yearn.
column3: Puissent-ils trouver l'action à laquelle ils aspirent.
column4: Mögen sie den Spaß finden, den sie so sehr suchen.
column6: Espero que encuentren la emoción que anhelan.

column2: Your son, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has decided to join with the Sons of Gwydion and seek his fortune at their side! Although he will no doubt gain both riches and valuable battle experience in service of the druids, there will be many perils that could well cost him his life.
column3: Votre fils, [From.GetTitledFirstName], a décidé de s'enrôler dans la Garde varègue à Miklagård et d'y chercher fortune ! Même si le fait d'être au service du roi grec va sans doute l'enrichir d'une importante expérience de combat, de nombreux dangers pourront lui coûter la vie.
column4: Euer Sohn, [From.GetTitledFirstName], hat beschlossen, sich der Warägergarde in Miklagard anzuschließen und dort sein Glück zu suchen. Obschon er zweifellos sowohl Reichtum als auch wertvolle Kampferfahrung im Dienst des Griechenkönigs finden wird, gibt es viele Gefahren, die ihn sein Leben kosten könnten.
column6: ¡Tu hijo, [From.GetTitledFirstName], ha decidido alistarse con la Guardia Varangian en Miklagård y buscar fortuna allí! Aunque, sin duda, obtendrá riquezas y valiosa experiencia en batalla al servicio del rey Griego, habrá muchos peligros que bien podrían costarle la vida.

column2: Go to the Circle and make me proud, son.
column3: Fils, va à Miklagård et fais-moi honneur.
column4: Gehe nach Miklagard und mache mich stolz, mein Sohn.
column6: Vete a Miklagård y hazme sentirme orgulloso, hijo.

column2: A heavily scarred warrior clad in strange Ogham inscribed armor approaches your throne, and before he can be disarmed, the stranger relieves your guard of his spear in a swift, fluid motion and tosses it aside. Other guards hurry forward, but you raise your hand to stop them. The stranger is [From.GetTitledFirstName], at last returned from the sons of Gwydion!
column3: Un guerrier profondément balafré, revêtu d'une étrange armure, s'approche de votre trône et, avant qu'on n'ait pu le désarmer, l'étranger, d'un mouvement prompt et adroit, désarme votre garde et jette sa lance par terre. Les autres gardes s'approchent en vitesse, mais vous levez votre bras pour les arrêter. L'étranger est [From.GetTitledFirstName], enfin revenu de Grèce !
column4: Ein vernarbter Krieger in seltsamer Rüstung erscheint vor Eurem Thron und bevor er entwaffnet werden kann, entreißt der Fremde Eurer Wache den Speer und wirft ihn beiseite. Andere Wachen eilen heran, doch Ihr hebt die Hand um sie aufzuhalten. Der Fremde ist [From.GetTitledFirstName] und endlich aus Griechenland heimgekehrt!
column6: Un guerrero con grandes cicatrices y vestido con una extraña armadura se acerca a tu trono, y antes de que pueda ser desarmado, el desconocido se quita de encima a la guardia con un movimiento rápido y fluido de su lanza, y la arroja a un lado. Otros guardias se apresuran hacia él, pero levantas la mano para detenerlos. ¡El desconocido es [From.GetTitledFirstName], por fin ha regresado de Grecia!

column2: A frail, robed man is led into your throne room, and your guards explain that he just arrived on a caravan coming from the Circle. The man would only speak your name over and over again, and so he was brought to you. To your horror, you recognize him at last as [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column3: Un homme frêle et vêtu d'une robe est mené dans votre salle du trône et vos gardes expliquent qu'il vient tout juste de débarquer d'un navire en provenance de Miklagård. L'homme répétait inlassablement le même mot : votre nom. Vous frémissez d'horreur en le reconnaissant, c'est [From.GetTitledFirstName] !
column4: Ein gebrechlicher, berobter Man wird in Euren Thronsaal geführt und Eure Wachen erklären, dass er gerade mit dem Schiff von Miklagard eingetroffen ist. Der Mann sprach nur wieder und wieder Euren Namen, daher wurde er zu Euch gebracht. Voller Erschrecken erkennt Ihr ihn schließlich als [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column6: Un hombre frágil vestido con túnica es conducido a tu sala del trono, y tus guardias explican que acaba de llegar en un barco procedente de Miklagård. El hombre sólo dice tu nombre una y otra vez, y por eso lo han llevado a ti. Para tu horror, ¡lo reconoces por fin como [From.GetTitledFirstName]!

column2: [From.GetFirstName], what have they done to you?!
column4: [From.GetFirstName], was haben sie mit Euch angestellt?

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally returned home after a long and successful time with the Sons of Gwydion! He fought in several battles, and learned much from the clever strategies and tactics favored by the band in their raids.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est finalement de retour au bercail après une fructueuse et longue carrière dans la Garde varègue ! Il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et a beaucoup appris sur les adroites stratégies et les tactiques utilisées par les Grecs et leurs ennemis au Serkland.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist nach langer und erfolgreicher Karriere in der Warägergarde endlich heimgekehrt! Er hat in vielen Schlachten gefochten und vieles von den schlauen Strategien und Taktiken der Griechen und ihrer Feinde in Serkland erfahren.
column6: ¡[From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha vuelto a casa después de una larga y exitosa carrera en la Guardia Varangiana! Luchó en varias batallas, y aprendió mucho de las inteligentes estrategias y las tácticas preferidas tanto por los griegos como por sus enemigos en Serkland.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from the Circle and the Sons of Gwydion, but he refuses to speak of his experiences there. You know he took part in several battles and killed many foes, but instead of reveling in the glory of his accomplishments, [From.GetFirstName] is plagued by nightmares and jumps at sudden sounds.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour de Grèce et de la Garde varègue, mais refuse de parler de son expérience là-bas. Vous savez qu'il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et qu'il a eu raison de nombreux ennemis, mais au lieu de raconter ses glorieux exploits, [From.GetFirstName] fait des cauchemars toutes les nuits et sursaute au moindre bruit.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Griechenland und der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt, aber er weigert sich, von seinen Erlebnissen zu sprechen. Ihr wisst, dass er an etlichen Schlachten teilgenommen und viele Feinde erschlagen hat, doch statt seine glorreichen Erfolge zu feiern, wird [From.GetFirstName] von Alpträumen geplagt und erschreckt bei plötzlichen Geräuschen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha regresado de Grecia y de la Guardia Varangiana, pero se niega a hablar de sus experiencias allí. Tú sabes que participó en varias batallas y mató a muchos enemigos, pero en vez de deleitarse en la gloria de sus logros, [From.GetFirstName] está plagado de pesadillas y salta con los ruidos repentinos.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has come home from the Circle and his service with the Sons of Gwydion, but he is not alone. He has found a wife and brought her with him. She seems loyal and well versed in the ways of the godsshe will make a good wife.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour de Miklagård et de son service dans la Garde varègue, mais il ne revient pas seul. Il s'est marié à une Grecque et l'a ramenée avec elle. Elle n'est pas habituée à nos coutumes et à notre langue, et ne semble pas apprécier notre climat, mais elle semble vouloir faire d'ici son chez soi.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Miklagard und seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde heimgekehrt. Er hat eine griechische Braut gefunden und mitgebracht. Sie kennt unsere Gebräuche und Sprache nicht und das Wetter hier scheint ihr nicht gut zu tun, doch sie ist willig, das Beste aus ihrem neuen Heim zu machen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha llegado a casa de Miklagård y de su servicio con la Guardia Varangiana, pero no está solo. Ha encontrado una esposa griega y la trajo con él. Ella no conoce nuestras costumbres ni el idioma, y el clima no le gusta demasiado, pero parece estar dispuesta a hacer lo mejor de su nuevo hogar.

column2: After many years at the Circle and around Britain, [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally been released from his service with the Sons of Gwydion and has returned home. Your son is a changed man, however. Secular matters no longer hold any interest for him, and he instead speaks incessantly of the Otherworld and the wonders of the Circle...
column3: Après plusieurs années en Grèce, [From.GetTitledFirstName] a enfin été dégagé de ses fonctions dans la Garde varègue et est rentré au bercail. Votre fils est cependant un homme changé. Les Anciens Dieux ne l'intéressent plus et il parle sans cesse du royaume des chrétiens et des horreurs qui s'abattront sur ceux qui refusent de se convertir...
column4: Nach vielen Jahren in Griechenland, wurde [From.GetTitledFirstName] endlich aus seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde entlassen und ist heimgekehrt. Doch Euer Sohn ist ein gewandelter Mann. Die alten Götter interessieren ihn nicht länger, stattdessen spricht er ununterbrochen vom Christentum und den Schrecken, die jene erwarten, die nicht konvertieren...
column6: Tras muchos años en Grecia, [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha sido finalmente liberado de su servicio a la Guardia Varangiana y ha regresado a casa. Sin embargo, tu hijo ha cambiado. Los viejos dioses ya no le interesan, y en cambio habla sin cesar de la Cristiandad y los horrores que le esperan a aquellos que se niegan a convertirse...

column2: I knew those druids would be a bad influence.
column3: Je savais que ces Grecs auraient une mauvaise influence.
column4: Ich wusste, dass diese Griechen ein schlechter Einfluss sein würden.
column6: Sabía que los Griegos serían una mala influencia.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from the Circle and the Sons of Gwydion as a changed man. He is wiser, more confident in his own abilities and more knowledgable in matters of war. It seems the time spent with the Wolflings did him good.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName]est de retour de Miklagård et de la Garde varègue et c'est un homme changé. Il est plus sage, plus sûr de lui et connaît très bien l'art de la guerre. Le temps qu'il a passé en Grèce semble lui avoir fait du bien.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist als gewandelter Mann aus Miklagard und dem Dienst in der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt. Er ist weiser, zuversichtlicher und besitzt neue Kenntnisse in Kriegsangelegenheiten. Es scheint, als habe ihm die Zeit bei den Griechen gut getan.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha vuelto de Miklagård y de la Guardia Varangiana como un hombre cambiado. Es más sabio, más seguro de sus propias habilidades y más eficiente en asuntos de guerra. Parece que el tiempo pasado en Grecia le ha hecho bien.

column2: Several former Wolves of the Sons of Gwydion have recently returned home after serving the Circle, and they bring news most grave. Your son, [From.GetTitledFirstName], fell in battle while raiding in the south. They assure you that he faced his enemy with bravery and slew many before their numbers overwhelmed him.
column3: Plusieurs anciens gardes varègues sont de retour de leur service pour le roi des Grecs depuis peu et ils apportent de mauvaises nouvelles. Votre fils, [From.GetTitledFirstName], est tombé au combat lors de la campagne du Serkland. Ils vous assurent qu'il a affronté l'ennemi avec bravoure et qu'il en a tué plusieurs avant qu'ils aient eu raison de lui.
column4: Einige frühere Waräger Gardisten sind von ihrem Dienst beim Griechenkönig heimgekehrt und bringen schlechteste Neuigkeiten mit. Euer Sohn [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist in einer Schlacht in Serkland gefallen. Sie versichern Euch, dass er seinem Feind mit Tapferkeit begegnet ist und viele erschlug, bevor ihre schiere Zahl ihn überwältigte.
column6: Varios ex guardias Varangianos han regresado recientemente a casa después de servir al rey Griego, y traen noticias graves. Tu hijo, [From.GetTitledFirstName], cayó en la batalla mientras estaba de campaña en Serkland. Te aseguran que se enfrentó a su enemigo con valentía y que mató a muchos antes de que sus números lo abrumaron.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has at last returned from the circle in a caravan filled with the spoils of war! Apparently the great druids are generous to those who serve the gods well, and there is gold here from all over the world. Your son insists on sharing these riches with you, his loving father.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est enfin de retour de Grèce, à bord d'un drakkar contenant un impressionnant butin de guerre ! Le grand roi des Grecs est apparemment très généreux avec ceux qui le servent bien, et il y a de l'or de tous les coins de la Grèce, du Serkland et de plus loin encore. Votre fils insiste pour partager ses richesses avec vous, son père bien-aimé.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist endlich aus Griechenland heimgekehrt, auf einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit Kriegsbeute. Offenbar ist der Griechenkönig großzügig gegenüber jenen, die ihm gut dienen. Hier findet sich Gold aus allen Ecken Griechenlands, Serklands und darüber hinaus. Euer Sohn besteht darauf, den Reichtum mit Euch, seinem Vater, zu teilen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha regresado de Grecia en un drakkar lleno de botines de guerra! Al parecer, el gran rey de los Griegos es generoso con los que le sirven bien, y hay oro aquí de todas partes del reino griego, Serkland y más allá. Tu hijo insiste en compartir estas riquezas contigo, su querido padre.

column2: Upon learning of the death of your father, you left the Sons of Gwydion and departed the Circle for home in a caravan filled with loot from your campaigns. It was a long and perilous journey back, but your feet are now firmly planted on the soil of the land that is your birthright. The throne is yours.
column3: Après avoir appris la mort de votre père, vous avez abandonné la Garde varègue et quittez Miklagård sur un drakkar pour rentrer au bercail, rapportant un important butin amassé lors de vos campagnes en Serkland. Le voyage du retour fut long et périlleux, mais vos pieds foulent maintenant la terre ferme, cette terre dont vous êtes l'héritier. Le trône est à vous.
column4: Als Ihr vom Tod Eures Vaters erfahrt, verlasst Ihr die Warägergarde und Miklagard in einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit der Beute Eurer Schlachten in Serkland. Es war eine lange und gefahrvolle Reise, doch jetzt setzt Ihr Eure Füße auf heimatliche Erde, dir Euer Geburtsrecht ist. Der Thron gehört Euch.
column6: Al enterarte de la muerte de tu padre, dejas la Guardia Varangiana y dejas Miklagard para volver a casa en un drakkar lleno de botines de tus campañas en Serkland. Fue un largo y peligroso viaje de regreso, pero tus pies están ahora firmemente plantados en la tierra que es tu patrimonio. El trono es tuyo.

column2: It is as I remember it.
column6: Es tal y como lo recordaba.

column2: You have decided to fund the Fianna, a sacred band of warriors loyal only to the Druids and to the Gods, dressed in wolf skins over mail and venerating the famed warriors Fionn and Cuchullain.\n\nThis new warband will not only form a powerful shock force against the isle's many enemies, but will also channel the fiery spirits of the younger, restless sons of the Éire.
column3: Les pillards varègues qui, depuis le nord lointain, voguent sur les fleuves qui se jettent dans la mer Noire, ont prouvé qu'ils étaient de redoutables guerriers. Vous avez réussi à recruter un grand nombre d'entre eux pour monter une garde personnelle de soldats totalement loyaux envers leur [Root.GetTitle].\n\nL'avantage de cette nouvelle Garde varègue est non seulement de former une puissante force de frappe contre les nombreux ennemis de l'empire, mais aussi d'être détachée, par ses racines étrangères, des complots et des jeux de pouvoir qui ont lieu au palais et qui sont monnaie courante à Constantinople.
column4: Warägerräuber, die aus dem fernen Norden die Flüsse bis zum Schwarzen Meer segelten, haben sich als herausragende Krieger erwiesen. Euch ist es gelungen, eine große Anzahl von ihnen als Leibwache zu rekrutieren, die nur gegenüber dem [Root.GetTitle] loyal ist.\n\n Diese neue Warägergarde stellt nicht nur eine mächtige Stoßtruppe dar, ihre ausländische Herkunft sollte auch sicherstellen, dass sie nicht allzu sehr in die Intrigen und Machtspiele verwickelt werden, die so typisch für Konstantinopel sind.
column6: Los invasores Varangianos navegando desde el lejano norte por los ríos que llevan al Mar Negro han demostrado ser guerreros formidables. Tú has logrado reclutar un gran número de ellos para una guardia personal leal sólo al [Root.GetTitle].\n\nEsta nueva Guardia Varangiana no sólo formará una gran fuerza contra los muchos enemigos del Imperio, sino que también sus raíces extranjeras impedirán que se enreden demasiado en la intriga palaciega y las luchas de poder que son tan comunes en Constantinopla.

column2: [From.GetFirstName], the great king of the Gaels, is distraught over the ravages braught over by our landless sons. Knowing well their need for battle, he has decided to encourage a sacred band of brothers known as the Fianna.\n\nThose who serve him and the Druids are generously rewarded, and even now many of our young men, eager for riches and adventure, have departed to pick up and honor Fionn's old name.
column3: [From.GetFirstName], le grand roi des Grecs, est angoissé par le peu de courage de ses compatriotes. Connaissant bien notre aptitude au combat, il a décidé de composer son équipe de gardes du corps uniquement de guerriers nordiques.\n\nCeux qui le servent dans la grande cité de Miklagård sont généreusement récompensés et, aujourd'hui encore, les jeunes hommes avides de richesse et d'aventure quittent pour la Grèce afin de le servir.
column4: [From.GetFirstName], der große König der Griechen, ist bestürzt über den lausigen Eifer seiner Landsmänner. Euren Kampfesmut kennend, hat er beschlossen, eine Leibwache nur aus nordischen Kriegern aufzustellen.\n\nWer ihm in Miklagard dient, wird reich belohnt und viele Eurer jungen Männer, erpicht auf Gold und Abenteuer, sind nach Griechenland abgereist, um in seinen Dienst zu treten.
column6: [From.GetFirstName], el gran rey de los Griegos, está perturbado por el poco ánimo de sus compatriotas. Conociendo bien nuestra habilidad en la batalla, ha decidido formar una guardia que consiste únicamente de guerreros Nórdicos.\n\nAquellos que le sirven en la gran ciudad de Miklagård son generosamente recompensados, e incluso ahora muchos de nuestros jóvenes, ávidos de riquezas y aventura, han partido hacia Grecia para levantar su estandarte.

column2: May they find the excitement they yearn.
column3: Puissent-ils trouver l'action à laquelle ils aspirent.
column4: Mögen sie den Spaß finden, den sie so sehr suchen.
column6: Espero que encuentren la emoción que anhelan.

column2: Your son, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has decided to join with the Fianna and seek his fortune at their side! Although he will no doubt gain both riches and valuable battle experience in service of the druids, there will be many perils that could well cost him his life.
column3: Votre fils, [From.GetTitledFirstName], a décidé de s'enrôler dans la Garde varègue à Miklagård et d'y chercher fortune ! Même si le fait d'être au service du roi grec va sans doute l'enrichir d'une importante expérience de combat, de nombreux dangers pourront lui coûter la vie.
column4: Euer Sohn, [From.GetTitledFirstName], hat beschlossen, sich der Warägergarde in Miklagard anzuschließen und dort sein Glück zu suchen. Obschon er zweifellos sowohl Reichtum als auch wertvolle Kampferfahrung im Dienst des Griechenkönigs finden wird, gibt es viele Gefahren, die ihn sein Leben kosten könnten.
column6: ¡Tu hijo, [From.GetTitledFirstName], ha decidido alistarse con la Guardia Varangian en Miklagård y buscar fortuna allí! Aunque, sin duda, obtendrá riquezas y valiosa experiencia en batalla al servicio del rey Griego, habrá muchos peligros que bien podrían costarle la vida.

column2: Go to the Circle and make me proud, son.
column3: Fils, va à Miklagård et fais-moi honneur.
column4: Gehe nach Miklagard und mache mich stolz, mein Sohn.
column6: Vete a Miklagård y hazme sentirme orgulloso, hijo.

column2: A heavily scarred warrior clad in strange Ogham inscribed armor approaches your throne, and before he can be disarmed, the stranger relieves your guard of his spear in a swift, fluid motion and tosses it aside. Other guards hurry forward, but you raise your hand to stop them. The stranger is [From.GetTitledFirstName], at last returned from the Fianna!
column3: Un guerrier profondément balafré, revêtu d'une étrange armure, s'approche de votre trône et, avant qu'on n'ait pu le désarmer, l'étranger, d'un mouvement prompt et adroit, désarme votre garde et jette sa lance par terre. Les autres gardes s'approchent en vitesse, mais vous levez votre bras pour les arrêter. L'étranger est [From.GetTitledFirstName], enfin revenu de Grèce !
column4: Ein vernarbter Krieger in seltsamer Rüstung erscheint vor Eurem Thron und bevor er entwaffnet werden kann, entreißt der Fremde Eurer Wache den Speer und wirft ihn beiseite. Andere Wachen eilen heran, doch Ihr hebt die Hand um sie aufzuhalten. Der Fremde ist [From.GetTitledFirstName] und endlich aus Griechenland heimgekehrt!
column6: Un guerrero con grandes cicatrices y vestido con una extraña armadura se acerca a tu trono, y antes de que pueda ser desarmado, el desconocido se quita de encima a la guardia con un movimiento rápido y fluido de su lanza, y la arroja a un lado. Otros guardias se apresuran hacia él, pero levantas la mano para detenerlos. ¡El desconocido es [From.GetTitledFirstName], por fin ha regresado de Grecia!

column2: A frail, robed man is led into your throne room, and your guards explain that he just arrived on a caravan coming from the Circle. The man would only speak your name over and over again, and so he was brought to you. To your horror, you recognize him at last as [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column3: Un homme frêle et vêtu d'une robe est mené dans votre salle du trône et vos gardes expliquent qu'il vient tout juste de débarquer d'un navire en provenance de Miklagård. L'homme répétait inlassablement le même mot : votre nom. Vous frémissez d'horreur en le reconnaissant, c'est [From.GetTitledFirstName] !
column4: Ein gebrechlicher, berobter Man wird in Euren Thronsaal geführt und Eure Wachen erklären, dass er gerade mit dem Schiff von Miklagard eingetroffen ist. Der Mann sprach nur wieder und wieder Euren Namen, daher wurde er zu Euch gebracht. Voller Erschrecken erkennt Ihr ihn schließlich als [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column6: Un hombre frágil vestido con túnica es conducido a tu sala del trono, y tus guardias explican que acaba de llegar en un barco procedente de Miklagård. El hombre sólo dice tu nombre una y otra vez, y por eso lo han llevado a ti. Para tu horror, ¡lo reconoces por fin como [From.GetTitledFirstName]!

column2: [From.GetFirstName], what have they done to you?!
column4: [From.GetFirstName], was haben sie mit Euch angestellt?

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally returned home after a long and successful time with the Fianna! He fought in several battles, and learned much from the clever strategies and tactics favored by the band in their raids.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est finalement de retour au bercail après une fructueuse et longue carrière dans la Garde varègue ! Il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et a beaucoup appris sur les adroites stratégies et les tactiques utilisées par les Grecs et leurs ennemis au Serkland.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist nach langer und erfolgreicher Karriere in der Warägergarde endlich heimgekehrt! Er hat in vielen Schlachten gefochten und vieles von den schlauen Strategien und Taktiken der Griechen und ihrer Feinde in Serkland erfahren.
column6: ¡[From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha vuelto a casa después de una larga y exitosa carrera en la Guardia Varangiana! Luchó en varias batallas, y aprendió mucho de las inteligentes estrategias y las tácticas preferidas tanto por los griegos como por sus enemigos en Serkland.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from the Circle and the Fianna, but he refuses to speak of his experiences there. You know he took part in several battles and killed many foes, but instead of reveling in the glory of his accomplishments, [From.GetFirstName] is plagued by nightmares and jumps at sudden sounds.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour de Grèce et de la Garde varègue, mais refuse de parler de son expérience là-bas. Vous savez qu'il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et qu'il a eu raison de nombreux ennemis, mais au lieu de raconter ses glorieux exploits, [From.GetFirstName] fait des cauchemars toutes les nuits et sursaute au moindre bruit.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Griechenland und der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt, aber er weigert sich, von seinen Erlebnissen zu sprechen. Ihr wisst, dass er an etlichen Schlachten teilgenommen und viele Feinde erschlagen hat, doch statt seine glorreichen Erfolge zu feiern, wird [From.GetFirstName] von Alpträumen geplagt und erschreckt bei plötzlichen Geräuschen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha regresado de Grecia y de la Guardia Varangiana, pero se niega a hablar de sus experiencias allí. Tú sabes que participó en varias batallas y mató a muchos enemigos, pero en vez de deleitarse en la gloria de sus logros, [From.GetFirstName] está plagado de pesadillas y salta con los ruidos repentinos.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has come home from the Circle and his service with the Fianna, but he is not alone. He has found a wife and brought her with him. She seems loyal and well versed in the ways of the gods, she will make a good wife.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour de Miklagård et de son service dans la Garde varègue, mais il ne revient pas seul. Il s'est marié à une Grecque et l'a ramenée avec elle. Elle n'est pas habituée à nos coutumes et à notre langue, et ne semble pas apprécier notre climat, mais elle semble vouloir faire d'ici son chez soi.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Miklagard und seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde heimgekehrt. Er hat eine griechische Braut gefunden und mitgebracht. Sie kennt unsere Gebräuche und Sprache nicht und das Wetter hier scheint ihr nicht gut zu tun, doch sie ist willig, das Beste aus ihrem neuen Heim zu machen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha llegado a casa de Miklagård y de su servicio con la Guardia Varangiana, pero no está solo. Ha encontrado una esposa griega y la trajo con él. Ella no conoce nuestras costumbres ni el idioma, y el clima no le gusta demasiado, pero parece estar dispuesta a hacer lo mejor de su nuevo hogar.

column2: After many years at the Circle and around the British isles, [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally been released from his service with the Fianna and has returned home. Your son is a changed man, however. Secular matters no longer hold any interest for him, and he instead speaks incessantly of the Otherworld and the wonders of the Circle...
column3: Après plusieurs années en Grèce, [From.GetTitledFirstName] a enfin été dégagé de ses fonctions dans la Garde varègue et est rentré au bercail. Votre fils est cependant un homme changé. Les Anciens Dieux ne l'intéressent plus et il parle sans cesse du royaume des chrétiens et des horreurs qui s'abattront sur ceux qui refusent de se convertir...
column4: Nach vielen Jahren in Griechenland, wurde [From.GetTitledFirstName] endlich aus seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde entlassen und ist heimgekehrt. Doch Euer Sohn ist ein gewandelter Mann. Die alten Götter interessieren ihn nicht länger, stattdessen spricht er ununterbrochen vom Christentum und den Schrecken, die jene erwarten, die nicht konvertieren...
column6: Tras muchos años en Grecia, [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha sido finalmente liberado de su servicio a la Guardia Varangiana y ha regresado a casa. Sin embargo, tu hijo ha cambiado. Los viejos dioses ya no le interesan, y en cambio habla sin cesar de la Cristiandad y los horrores que le esperan a aquellos que se niegan a convertirse...

column2: I knew those druids would be a bad influence.
column3: Je savais que ces Grecs auraient une mauvaise influence.
column4: Ich wusste, dass diese Griechen ein schlechter Einfluss sein würden.
column6: Sabía que los Griegos serían una mala influencia.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from the Circle and the Fianna as a changed man. He is wiser, more confident in his own abilities and more knowledgable in matters of war. It seems the time spent in a Fian did him good.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName]est de retour de Miklagård et de la Garde varègue et c'est un homme changé. Il est plus sage, plus sûr de lui et connaît très bien l'art de la guerre. Le temps qu'il a passé en Grèce semble lui avoir fait du bien.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist als gewandelter Mann aus Miklagard und dem Dienst in der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt. Er ist weiser, zuversichtlicher und besitzt neue Kenntnisse in Kriegsangelegenheiten. Es scheint, als habe ihm die Zeit bei den Griechen gut getan.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha vuelto de Miklagård y de la Guardia Varangiana como un hombre cambiado. Es más sabio, más seguro de sus propias habilidades y más eficiente en asuntos de guerra. Parece que el tiempo pasado en Grecia le ha hecho bien.

column2: Several former Fennid of the Fianna have recently returned home after serving the Circle, and they bring news most grave. Your son, [From.GetTitledFirstName], fell in battle while raiding in the south. They assure you that he faced his enemy with bravery and slew many before their numbers overwhelmed him.
column3: Plusieurs anciens gardes varègues sont de retour de leur service pour le roi des Grecs depuis peu et ils apportent de mauvaises nouvelles. Votre fils, [From.GetTitledFirstName], est tombé au combat lors de la campagne du Serkland. Ils vous assurent qu'il a affronté l'ennemi avec bravoure et qu'il en a tué plusieurs avant qu'ils aient eu raison de lui.
column4: Einige frühere Waräger Gardisten sind von ihrem Dienst beim Griechenkönig heimgekehrt und bringen schlechteste Neuigkeiten mit. Euer Sohn [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist in einer Schlacht in Serkland gefallen. Sie versichern Euch, dass er seinem Feind mit Tapferkeit begegnet ist und viele erschlug, bevor ihre schiere Zahl ihn überwältigte.
column6: Varios ex guardias Varangianos han regresado recientemente a casa después de servir al rey Griego, y traen noticias graves. Tu hijo, [From.GetTitledFirstName], cayó en la batalla mientras estaba de campaña en Serkland. Te aseguran que se enfrentó a su enemigo con valentía y que mató a muchos antes de que sus números lo abrumaron.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has at last returned from the circle in a caravan filled with the spoils of war! Apparently the great druids are generous to those who serve the gods well, and there is gold here from all over the world. Your son insists on sharing these riches with you, his loving father.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est enfin de retour de Grèce, à bord d'un drakkar contenant un impressionnant butin de guerre ! Le grand roi des Grecs est apparemment très généreux avec ceux qui le servent bien, et il y a de l'or de tous les coins de la Grèce, du Serkland et de plus loin encore. Votre fils insiste pour partager ses richesses avec vous, son père bien-aimé.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist endlich aus Griechenland heimgekehrt, auf einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit Kriegsbeute. Offenbar ist der Griechenkönig großzügig gegenüber jenen, die ihm gut dienen. Hier findet sich Gold aus allen Ecken Griechenlands, Serklands und darüber hinaus. Euer Sohn besteht darauf, den Reichtum mit Euch, seinem Vater, zu teilen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha regresado de Grecia en un drakkar lleno de botines de guerra! Al parecer, el gran rey de los Griegos es generoso con los que le sirven bien, y hay oro aquí de todas partes del reino griego, Serkland y más allá. Tu hijo insiste en compartir estas riquezas contigo, su querido padre.

column2: Upon learning of the death of your father, you left the Fianna and departed the Circle for home in a caravan filled with loot from your campaigns. It was a long and perilous journey back, but your feet are now firmly planted on the soil of the land that is your birthright. The throne is yours.
column3: Après avoir appris la mort de votre père, vous avez abandonné la Garde varègue et quittez Miklagård sur un drakkar pour rentrer au bercail, rapportant un important butin amassé lors de vos campagnes en Serkland. Le voyage du retour fut long et périlleux, mais vos pieds foulent maintenant la terre ferme, cette terre dont vous êtes l'héritier. Le trône est à vous.
column4: Als Ihr vom Tod Eures Vaters erfahrt, verlasst Ihr die Warägergarde und Miklagard in einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit der Beute Eurer Schlachten in Serkland. Es war eine lange und gefahrvolle Reise, doch jetzt setzt Ihr Eure Füße auf heimatliche Erde, dir Euer Geburtsrecht ist. Der Thron gehört Euch.
column6: Al enterarte de la muerte de tu padre, dejas la Guardia Varangiana y dejas Miklagard para volver a casa en un drakkar lleno de botines de tus campañas en Serkland. Fue un largo y peligroso viaje de regreso, pero tus pies están ahora firmemente plantados en la tierra que es tu patrimonio. El trono es tuyo.

column2: It is as I remember it.
column6: Es tal y como lo recordaba.

column2: Our religion has been reformed, yet still the warbands of the Fianna run freely, many forgoing the authority of the Circle. By vassalizing their leader, we could further legitimise our rule and gain more control on their members.
A group of fennid warriors have come to visit [Root.PrimaryTitle.GetName]. [Root.job_chancellor.GetTitledFirstName] has met with them, and ask for my reply.
column3: Un groupe de chevaliers errants se présente à [Root.Location.GetName]. [Root.job_chancellor.GetTitledFirstName] les accueille et attend ma réponse.
column4: Eine Gruppe fahrender Ritter besucht [Root.Location.GetName]. [Root.job_chancellor.GetTitledFirstName] hat sich mit ihnen getroffen und wartet nun auf meine Antwort.
column6: Ha venido un grupo de Caballeros Errantes a visitar [Root.Location.GetName]. [Root.job_chancellor.GetTitledFirstName] se ha reunido con ellos y pide mi respuesta.

column2: Welcome them with a lavish feast!
column3: Qu’on organise un somptueux festin en leur honneur !
column4: Zu ihren Ehren ein üppiges Gelage geben!
column6: ¡Dales la bienvenida con una gran fiesta!

column2: The fennid warriors have participated in a minor brawl together with our own warriors in [Root.Location.GetName]. Sadly, one of those landless vagabonds has been severely injured.
column3: Les chevaliers errants participent à un tournoi avec nos chevaliers à [Root.Location.GetName]. Malheureusement, un de ces vagabonds sans terres est gravement blessé.
column4: Die fahrenden Ritter haben zusammen mit unseren Rittern in [Root.Location.GetName] an einem kleinen Turnier teilgenommen. Traurigerweise wurde dabei einer dieser landlosen Vagabunden schwer verwundet.
column6: Los Caballeros Errantes han celebrado un pequeño torneo con nuestros caballeros en [Root.Location.GetName]. Por desgracia, uno de esos vagabundos ha sido gravemente herido.

column2: Pay for some medication, and send them on their way
column3: Je paie ses médicaments et le renvoie.
column4: Für etwas Arznei bezahlen und sie dann weiterschicken
column6: Págales medicinas y que se vayan

column2: Allow them to stay at the castle while he recovers.
column3: Je lui permets de rester au château le temps qu’il se rétablisse.
column4: Sie dürfen in der Burg bleiben, bis er sich erholt hat
column6: Deja que se queden en el castillo hasta que se recupere.

column2: A young fennid has distinguished himself quite nicely in the time he has been at our castle.
column3: Un jeune chevalier errant se distingue brillamment au cours de son séjour dans notre château.
column4: Während seines Aufenthalts in unserer Burg hat sich ein junger fahrender Ritter besonders hervorgetan.
column6: Un joven caballero errante se ha distinguido en el tiempo que lleva en nuestro castillo.

column4: Er soll in unsere Dienste treten!

column2: A member of our court has taken great offense at the behavior of the rough uncut fianna visiting our castle. He almost demands that we should execute the vagrants.
column3: Un membre de notre Cour est choqué par la grossièreté des chevaliers errants qui séjournent dans notre château. Il est à deux doigts de réclamer l’exécution de ces vagabonds.
column4: Ein Mitglied unseres Hofes stört sich erheblich am Benehmen der rohen fahrenden Ritter, die auf Besuch in unserer Burg sind. Er geht fast so weit, die Hinrichtung der Landstreicher zu fordern.
column6: Un miembro de la corte se ha ofendido mucho por el comportamiento de los rudos caballeros errantes que visitan nuestro castillo. Casi pide que les ejecutemos.

column2: Throw the fianna out of the castle!
column3: Qu’on renvoie les chevaliers errants du château !
column4: Raus aus der Burg mit den fahrenden Rittern!
column6: ¡Echa del castillo a los caballeros errantes!

column2: A young woman has been seduced by one of the fianna. This seems to have some unforeseen consequences.
column3: Une jeune femme s’est laissé séduire par un des chevaliers errants, ce qui n’est pas sans conséquences.
column4: Einer der fahrenden Ritter hat eine junge Frau verführt. Dies scheint einige unvorhersehbare Konsequenzen zu haben.
column6: Una joven ha sido seducida por un caballero errante. Esto parece tener consecuencias imprevistas.

column2: Let them both stay at court.
column3: Ils peuvent tous les deux rester à la Cour !
column6: Dejemos que ambos se queden en la corte.

column2: The dungeon is a nice place for that 'warrior'.
column3: Le cachot conviendra très bien à ce 'chevalier'.
column4: Hoffentlich findet dieser 'Ritter' Gefallen an unserem Kerker.
column6: La mazmorra es un buen sitio para ese 'caballero'.

column2: The fianna are ready to depart our castle and ride forth to another lord's domain.
column3: Les chevaliers errants sont prêts à quitter notre château pour rejoindre le domaine d’un autre Seigneur.
column4: Die fahrenden Ritter sind bereit, unsere Burg zu verlassen und in die Domäne eines anderen Fürsten zu reiten.
column6: Los caballeros errantes están listos para salir de nuestro castillo y cabalgar al dominio de otro señor.

column3: Qu’on organise un festin d’adieu en leur honneur !
Qu’on les laisse s’en aller discrètement !
column4: Sie sollen sich leise auf den Weg machen.

column2: [Root.job_marshal.GetTitledFirstName] has arrested an armed man with ragged armor and a spotty horse. [Root.job_marshal.GetSheHeCap] says that the man claims to be a fian, but clearly does not believe that statement.
column3: [Root.job_marshal.GetTitledFirstName] a arrêté un homme armé avec une armure en piteux état et un cheval tacheté. L’homme prétend être un chevalier errant, mais [Root.job_marshal.GetTitledFirstName] ne le croit pas.
column4: [Root.job_marshal.GetTitledFirstName] hat einen bewaffneten Mann mit schartiger Rüstung und geflecktem Pferd verhaftet. [Root.job_marshal.GetSheHeCap] sagt, der Mann würde behaupten, ein fahrender Ritter zu sein. Dieser Aussage schenkt er aber offensichtlich keinen Glauben.
column6: [Root.job_marshal.GetTitledFirstName] ha arrestado a un hombre con una armadura estropeada y un caballo moteado. [Root.job_marshal.GetSheHeCap] dice que el hombre afirma ser un caballero errante, pero que no le cree.
Está claro que es un ladrón...

column2: With the help of our court wizard, we could reinstate much of the old celtic ways.
This character has taken up ancient celtic traditions.

A faint whisper draws your attention and you find a haggard old man in a dark corner of your castle. Before you have a chance to throw him out, he explains that he is a wizard. He claims to be powerful in the ways of the old gods, and he has come to offer you his services.
A man should keep eyes on all matters.

column3: Vous faites sortir cette misérable créature.
column4: Ihr schickt die elende Kreatur fort.

column2: The exploits of the heroes of old, of the High Kings of Albion, Eire and Alba, these stories bring up visions of a better time, when giants and fairies where friends, before man destroyed all in his folly. With the help of your court wizard, you have decided to adopt certain old celtic rites.
The spirits of the land must be appeased
Revolted by the resurgeance of old practices in your lands, a priest has come to your court, asking you to reform your ways.
Why limit myself to one God?
The Old Ways are barbarous, the power of God conquers all.
Your liege has started to follow the teachings of an unwashed pagan wizard and is reinstating old practices, as a celt, you find these ideas somewhat interesting...
The spirits of the land must be appeased
Your vasssal, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has adopted the celtic traditions you have instituted
Your vasssal, [From.GetTitledFirstName], has refused to adopt the celtic traditions you have instituted
Toc. Toc. Toc. \n\nThe sound of knocking on the doors wakes you up, as your eyes get used to the obscurity, the soft moonlight dripping into the room shines on the sturdy oak doors.

You crack open the door, peeking into the shrouds of darkness on the other side. At first you see nothing, but then, hearing a weary sound from below , you lower your eyes to the strangest of sights, a group of little men, with unusually long ears holding what seems to be an old, dying man on a flat shield. \n\nBewildered, your hear the nearest elf asking entrance for them and their king.

The peculiar procession makes its way inside your chambers and the elves tranfer their king on your bed. After a long, silent night, the old elf lets out a faint whisper and finally stiffens forevermore. \n\nStricken with grief, the elves ask for your guidance.
Yes, I will be King of the Elves!

Celtic paganism is one of the last surviving branch of the ancient druidic belief systems. A pantheon of gods and a world full of spirits , the children of Dana rule the Skies, the Earth and the Otherworld. The main gods are Dana and Nuada, Angus, the god of Youth, Macha, the horse goddess, the great Daghda, Manannan mac Lir, the Sea God and Lugh of the Long Spear. Defining features in-game:
§Y*§! Can raid neighbors for loot
§Y*§! Low-tech non-pagans have very low Supply Limit in Pagan counties
§Y*§! Can declare Subjugation Wars against all other pagans
§Y*§! Rulers are limited to Gavelkind Succession
§Y*§! Rulers cannot declare Holy Wars
§Y*§! Inferior at conversion and vulnerable to non-pagan missionaries
§Y*§! Rulers lose Prestige if at peace for too long
§Y*§! The Celtic Pagan faith can be Reformed

The reformed Celtic faith has a standardized liturgy etched on the many raised stones on the British Isles, telling the story of the Tuatha De Danann.. It is led by the circle of the Druids with the Arch-Druid as the religious leader of the faithful. Defining features in-game:\n§Y*§! Can raid neighbors for loot\n§Y*§! The Arch-Druid can call Great Holy Wars
An unwashed, mysterious pagan from the countryside, his powers are unclear, but they serve to appease the more occult worries of a ruler.
The best warrior of the land, the title of champion is a great honor among celtic peoples, their task is to protect their king.

The Teulu (literally meaning "family") are strongly armed and mounted retainers. Known individually as Uchelwr, these upper class warriors favour red tunics, and dress for battle in a similar style to the frankish knights, although armed with lances, the Uchelwr's throw javelins.

The vates were one of three classes of Celtic priesthood, the other two being the druids and the bards. The Vates had the role of seers and performed sacrifices (in particular administering human sacrifice) under the presidence of a druid.
Your injuries are a sign of weakness, following great Nuada's example, it would be wise to abdicate your throne for the safety of your people.
A serious injury to this ruler's body has made his rule illegitimate in the eyes of his people
You should not be seeing this (Bard Assign)
You should not be seeing this (Druid Assign)
Invite a Druid to your court - this can only be done every two years

The Druid's knowledge of the ancient Celtic ballads and of sacred traditions is great and their power among the Celts is without equal. They are responsible for organising worship and sacrifices, divination, and judicial procedure in Celtic society.
This druid has decided to use the ancient secrets of the druid for his own personal gain, his sacrilegious behavior is unfitting of a druid.

I have searched far and wide for a worthy Druid to serve at my court. He will organise worship and sacrifices, divination, and judicial procedure, encourage my warriors, and provide me counsel. At long last, one such man has arrived at my court, but I am not sure whether he is worthy... A ruler must choose his Druid wisely, after all.

I have searched far and wide for a worthy Druid to serve at my court. He will organise worship and sacrifices, divination, and judicial procedure, encourage my warriors, and provide me counsel. At long last, one such man has arrived at my court, but I am not sure whether he is worthy... A ruler must choose his Druid wisely, after all.
A lord must choose his Druid with care, for while all druids are wise, not all have specialised in the same teachings.
Send for a master of law.
Bring me a servant of the gods.

The people of your court are incredulous. “Great [Root.GetTitle], it is a shame that you do not have a Druid at court! Are you to be like a Bard without his voice, a warrior without his spear, a farmer without his seeds?” No self-respecting ruler of the islands can go without a Druid, after all.
I must find a knowledgeable Druid soon, and fast!
There seems to be a suitable candidate at my court
A Druid has just arrived in this lord's court.
Responsible for organising worship and sacrifices, divination, and judicial procedure in Celtic society, they are as essential to a ruler as his sword.

Bards were those who sang the songs recalling the tribal warriors' deeds of bravery as well as the genealogies and family histories of the ruling strata among Celtic societies. The Celtic peoples maintain an intricate oral history committed to memory and transmitted by bards. Bards facilitated the memorization of such materials by the use of metre, rhyme and other formulaic poetic devices.

Typically my Bard only provides performances to a select few at my court, entertaining us with stories, histories, jokes, and more. It is time that I organize something on a grander scale for the entire community. As a display of my capacity as [Root.GetTitle], I shall host a great performance led by my Bard.
Let me tell my Bard my thoughts.

“A good idea,” my Bard says, as we discuss my plan. “I will make preparations as soon as I can. You too, my liege, do your part in organizing this. Let the community know of your generosity!”\n”What sort of things are you planning to do?” I ask my Bard. “You must do many things - praise my ancestors, entertain the people, recall histories and great legends...”\n”Worry not,” my Bard says. “I think I have a good idea of what to do for this year’s performance. Just wait and see, my liege - as always, I will not disappoint. You and the community will be very much entertained. It will only be a matter of time.”

Your Bard has already given many wonderful performances! You and your audience are eager to hear more. Will your Bard tell of your ancestors’ heroic deeds next? Or maybe he’ll recount another adventure of the lazy genius Ouati and the ever-curious Kadi? Or perhaps he’ll start teasing some more people?
Let us hear more, my Bard, let us hear more!

What another wonderful series of performances by your Bard - it’s too bad these sort of large performances only happen every now and then. Everyone is amazed at how your Bard is able to spend hours on end recalling histories and legends, comedies and adventures, all from memory!
Maybe next time I can hear another story about...

Today my Bard sings of my ancestors’ heroic exploits. Look as he strums his kora harp! But his voice falters - is he tired? One of the audience members interrupts and makes some helpful criticism, as is custom among our people: “Perhaps your rhythm is too fast, respected Bard.”
Indeed, I agree. Sing slowly - we wish to ponder all you say.
No, I think his rhythm is fine.
No, be livelier! Imagine what my ancestor felt hunting elephants!

“The Hunters approached Chief Nuh, and wished an audience,” your Bard sings, as he continues his story. “But the Chief disagreed. ‘Nay,’ cried he, ‘I shall not meet with these beggars and scavengers.’” Someone in the audience cries, “What a fool Nuh is! To reject the mighty, nyama-wielding hunters!”
The hunters are powerful like Bards and Blacksmiths indeed!
If I remember this story right, Chief Nuh has a good reason for this.

“[Root.GetTitledFirstName]’s ancestor had to be careful as he snuck in the house, for though the wicked merchant was fat from all the food he ate, he was still sly like a hyena, and could hear even the smallest of sounds,” says your Bard, as he recounts a tale to your court. “But the wicked merchant had to be taught a lesson. Fate was on the side of [Root.GetTitledFirstName]’s ancestor. Though his cunning, he stole all of the wicked merchant’s baklava.”\nYour audience claps and cheers. Very good! That wicked merchant had it coming. So your Bard continues, “On eating one, [Root.GetTitledFirstName]’s ancestor remarked, ‘Wondrous is this delicacy eaten by the Greeks, heirs of Alexander the Great! A pity the wicked merchant had no recipes to steal!”
I wish my ancestor could have stolen the recipe.

“How many piled-up ruins! But all the deeds I have spoken of today took place long ago. [Root.GetTitle]s have succeeded [Root.GetTitle]s, but the land has always remained the same. So it was, so it is, and so it will be.” With that, your Bard concludes his story for the day.
A good tale! Tomorrow, why don’t you tell the story about...

“But [Root.GetTitledFirstName]’s father was brave, and mighty, and though his companions fled, he did not retreat when the lion came. He raised his spear, for he was ready to fight the lion. Then...” Your Bard pauses for dramatic effect, as everyone imagines the lion and your father circling each other.
And then? And then? What happens next?
Wait a moment... my father never told me about this!
My father didn’t kill lions, my Bard is making it all up.

“And Guimba the Tyrant died, the victim of the trap and his own hubris,” your Bard sings, ending the story. “Thus it is so, that tyrants will always fall, defeated by righteous men who follow the wisdom of [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName]. This is nothing but fate, for who can deny fate? One cannot change it.”\nYour Bard looks up, smiling, as he pauses for a moment. He then resumes playing his kora harp. “The universe has mysteries which none can fathom, even us Bards. Perhaps you will be born a great and mighty king - you can do nothing about it. Perhaps you will be unlucky and become a beggar - you can do nothing about it. Each man finds his way already marked for him and he can change nothing of it.”
Fate is quite a powerful thing indeed.
Fate is a silly idea used to scare children.

Today your Bard recounts your entire genealogy, to remind your court of the great men and women from which you descend. It is amazing, is it not, that your Bard knows so much about so many people who lived long ago? Even you learn new things about your ancestors now and then.
I bet my Bard made some of that up and made it sound convincing.
Actually, my Bard, you made a mistake about my great-great-great...

“The lad Ouati was a clever genius despite his laziness, always impressing the excitable, ever-curious lass Kadi with his mind,” your Bard sings, as he begins his performance. “Today, if you wish, I will tell of the two. Today, I will tell of how they and their friends solved another mystery in their village, the mystery of the iced cream...”\n”No, no,” one of your audience members interrupt, as is typical custom, “Tell us the one when the sorceress Nemiss tricked Ouati into doing her bidding!” Yet another member of your court, a scholarly sort, speaks his opinion, “I want to hear the one where Ouati and his friends debate about the mysteries of anger.” One more person speaks out, saying, “Those stories aren’t as exciting as the one with the Persian siblings and the bristle toothbrush!”
So many choices. Good thing my Bard can tell them all!

“‘I’m curious at what you’re thinking,’ said the lass Kadi, as the lad Ouati tried to figure out a way to escape the trap,” your Bard tells, continuing the story. “‘How will we escape these lions?’” You don’t know how, but in your heart you know the lazy genius Ouati always figures out a way out of the situation!
I’m curious too! What’s his ingenious solution this time?
Ha, I’ve already figured this one, Ouati will use Kadi’s headscarf to...

“‘...where my evil is law. Now the fool seeks to return to the past and undo the future that is Abubakari!’” your Bard sings in the melodramatic voice of the evil, shapeshifting sorcerer-king Abubakari. Indeed, you wonder, how will the warrior Soumaoro Yaqub undo Abubakari’s evil rule? Surely, the great villain Abu - as everyone calls him - is more than a mere sorcerer - he is a god, in a way.\nAs your Bard continues playing the song of Soumaoro Yaqub on his kora harp, you and your audience can’t wait to hear more of Soumaoro Yaqub’s endless quest to defeat the evil Abu. You’ve heard most of the stories about Soumaoro Yaqub, but you always enjoy hearing them again. Will your Bard tell of when the monkeys taught Yaqub learned to jump well? Or when Yaqub assisted the 300 Greek warriors against the Cattle-men?
How about the one when Yaqub lost all his clothes?

The audience roars with laughter as your Bard mimics your style of speech and movement during his performance. You can only grimace or do a weak laugh, for you know that the Bards have the right to mock and insult anyone, including their patron, even if that patron is a powerful [Root.GetTitle] like yourself.
Ah, well, it’s not that bad.
Fools! You’ll all pay for this... somehow...
Oh no, let me show you how you should do it!

“There lies a fabled land far, far away,” your Bard says in a low-tone, powerful and suspenseful. “This is a fearsome, barren land, where the fabled one-legged, one-eyed men live, they who are heathen cannibals! Today, the warrior Soumaoro Yaqub, in his quest to defeat the evil Abubakari, travels there...”
Will Soumaoro Yaqub undo Abubakari’s evil again?
Any scholar knows one-legged men live south of us, and they aren’t cannibals!

Today your Bard tells one of the comedic adventures of the perverted youth, Ali-Ali, who is always a lecher around pretty girls. But Ali-Ali also possesses some magical powers, being a sorcerer-in-training, so he always has to fight strange monstrosities terrorizing his village.
Is he facing the evil crab again?

“There once was a bandit named Ridwan the Red,” your Bard sings, beginning his performance for the day, “who came riding to Oualata from old Timbuktu, and the braggart did swagger and brandish his spear, as he told of bold battles and gold he had stole...”
Who’s going to humiliate that braggart this time?

“There was a land far, far away, that was once threatened by a flying menace,” your Bard says, as he recounts yet another tale. “The flying monsters were great and many, like a swarm of locusts - who would, who could, kill them all? None, until came the once-imprisoned, saintly Kibu’u...”
Bah, I’ve heard other Bards sing the same.

“You’ve solved this mystery and helped me much,’ the sorceress Namiss said, congratulating the lad Ouati, that lazy genius,” as your Bard continues his tale. But your audience is incredulous. One of your courtiers says, confused, “That makes no sense, that can’t be the ending, and Ouati... isn’t Namiss - “
Something is not right here... this story might not be over just yet...
Wait, I’ve heard this one before - the fools don’t see a plot twist coming!

What comedic adventures will Ali-Ali go through today? You listen eagerly as your Bard begins to tell another tale of the perverted young sorcerer, Ali-Ali.\n“The clever little snail goddess, Nana, greeted our hero the lusty Ali-Ali. ‘I greet you, Ali-Ali-Ali!’ she said mischievously to her friend,” your Bard sings. “‘My name is not Ali-Ali-Ali!’ said Ali-Ali, ‘It is Ali-Ali!’ To which Nana replied, ‘Sorry, I stuttered!’ And Ali-Ali said, ‘Do you mean it wasn’t on purpose? You! You silly snail! Don’t make me do something nasty!”
Wait, is it Arabi-Ali... Al-Hajj-Ali... Ali-Ali-Ali-Ali?
I’d like to eat some snail now that my Bard mentions it.
I definitely know what Ali-Ali means by “nasty.”

“[Root.GetTitledFirstName] is just , is [Root.GetSheHe] not? [Root.GetTitledFirstName] is kind, is [Root.GetSheHe] not? [Root.GetTitledFirstName] is mighty, is [Root.GetSheHe] not?” Your Bard sings as he plays his kora harp, the audience watching with rapt attention. “Indeed our [Root.GetTitle] is great, is [Root.GetSheHe] not?”
No, this praise is too much...  I have faults too!
This is not enough praise - speak of my other strengths!
I can’t believe the audience listens to and believes this nonsense about me.

As part of his performance, your Bard steps back and forth solemnly as he chants praises to the ancestors of your clan. There is something dignified yet eerie about him as he marches around. “In the beginning was the Word,” your Bard once told you, “And then Music. Like smiths who learned to create and destroy through tools, so too did we Bards learn to create and destroy through Word, and through Music.”\nSuddenly, a child in your court runs out towards the Bard. You grab the boy and pull him back. “Be careful!” you whisper in a harsh tone. “Do you know who that is? Did your parents tell you nothing? If you cross the path of the Bards, you may die! If they touch you, and they wish it, you may die!” This is no superstition - in your heart, you know this to be true. The Bard is truly a fearsome being who possesses great power.
Even a [Root.GetTitle] such as myself must be careful.
Even for all my skepticism, I cannot be skeptical of the Bard’s power.

Today, your Bard will take some time to tell fanciful tales to the children at your court. As you stand nearby, you can’t help but smile a bit as you recall your own childhood, and how your father’s Bard used to tell you exciting tales about the gods and heroes of your people.\n“What story should I tell?” your Bard asks, speaking to his audience, mostly children. “What of the trickster, Anansi the spider, who taught people how to weave cloth? Or how about the clever but lazy Ouati, who can solve any problem? Or what of the great warrior Soumaoro Yaqub, who seeks to undo the evil that is Abubakari?” The children all shout in chaotic disunion, as they demand to hear their favorite stories. You laugh a bit - you were once like that too, no?
As long as my Bard doesn't sing about Ali-Ali the lusty sorcerer.

As your Bard finishes yet another performance, the memory of all he has told us these past few days still rings fresh in your mind. Who knew the young sorcerer Ali-Ali could be so lustful, to scavenge after the dirty clothes of young maidens? Who knew my grandfather actually wrestled with five elephants? Who knew how the lazy genius Ouati got out of trouble yet again? And who knew I had so many good qualities?\nYour Bard knew all this. He once said, “My word is pure and free of untruth. It is the word of my father, his father, and his father, and so on as far back as anyone can remember.”\nYes. It must be so. It must have been since time immemorial. So you remember your Bard’s words, “Bards do not know what lying is.”
But for now, I should pay full attention to my Bard.

The trickster spirits are always a good topic for the Bards to talk about. Their stories are always full of mischievousness, perfect for all audiences. And so it is that your Bard tells about one such trickster today.\n”One day the trickster Takoi wore a hat, white on one side and red the other,” your Bard sings. “As he walked down the road, some people said his hat was white, but others said it was red. The people began to bicker about the color. White! Red! Red! White! They got so angry, they began to fight and hurt each other. Seeing this, Takoi laughed, exclaiming, ‘People will fight over anything!’”
People tend to be like this all the time.

Your Bard continues, “The hero Soumaoro Yaqub came across a strange man from Frangistan, a one-legged warrior wielding a large sword - “
”The man shouldn’t be from Frangistan,” one of your courtiers interrupts. He suggests something else, as is custom, “I think he should be a Persian!”
 “Make him a Roman! From Constantinople! Romans are amazing,” says another member of the audience.
”Whoever likes the decadent Romans are imbeciles,” cuts in another person, “The warrior should be from mystical Cathay!”
As the audience continues arguing, you see your Bard looks rather confused.
Ignore the fools, choose whatever you want.
I think the warrior should come from...

“And you,” your Bard sings, looking at one of your courtiers, “the people say you eat too much, and your feces are of many colors - yellow, blue, red, green, purple!”\nThe audience laughs as your gluttonous courtier blushes in embarrassment. “And you,” the Bard sings, continuing his tirade of mockery, “You there, the people say you are a lech, like the young sorcerer Ali-Ali was - but you are three times his age. What are you doing, chasing your granddaughter’s friends, dirty old man?”\nAnd now the Bard turns to yet another person. “And you, ah, you. The people say...”
My Bard, talk about my flaws too.
Talk of my children, that they learn from their flaws.

“Of whose ancestors should I speak?” your Bard shouts, “Should I speak of your lineage of leatherworkers, Bonga? For I knew your grandfather well, he was a hard-working man. Or, perhaps, I should tell of your mighty lineage of hunters, Kassa?”\nA few members of the audience make their suggestions, before your Bard decides. “Very well! Listen then to my word, for I will tell you of the ancestors of the jeweler Sakoura. They are brave men, this lineage, who show their strength not through force of arms like warriors or hunters, but through their craft and through their shrewdness. Let me tell of how Sakoura’s great-grandfather Fodi foiled the evil Tuareg chief Ilyas with his wits, with nothing but some Greek pastries and some silver rings...”
Now this sounds like a good story...
Preparations for the performance are made - everybody can't wait!

The day of the performance has dawned. Your Bard, dressed in his finest attire, holds in his hand a kora harp - the sweet, delicate, yet powerful instrument of the Bards - as he presents himself before the community. What sort of stories will he tell? What sort of people will he mock? What ancestors will he honor? For the next few days, you and the community will bear witness to these, and more, perhaps for hours on end.\nIt is custom among the peoples of the savanna that the audience can make suggestions (or even constructive criticisms) to the Bard throughout his performance. Since you are the highest-ranked member of the community present, your Bard allows you to make a suggestion first. “What would I like to hear?” you think to yourself. There are so many things to hear of - too many, for the Bards know much. So many choices indeed!
I think we should start with the story about...
Today your child comes of age. [From.GetSheHeCap] will join the clan today as the Druids present [From.GetHerHim] to the gods. You can use this opportunity to plan [From.GetHerHis] future.
The Gods are in need of [From.GetHerHim]
Today is the day I become an adult, it is time I meet my destiny
Your child will undergo training with the warriors\n
Your child will undergo training with the druids\n

An old man has arrived, dressed in the garbs of a druid, he is here to take your child with him to a sacred grove deep inside the forest.\nThere [From.GetSheHe] will be taught the secret arts of the druids, this training will take many years and novices have been known to come back changed, or worse... dead.

Your child has expressed a peculiar wish, unsatisfied with the life of a warrior, [From.GetSheHe] wishes to learn the druidic arts and become closer to the gods. \nBut that way is strange and dangerous, not all survive it.
Yes, this will bring great honor to our family.

The night is dark and cold when your servants wake you, a visitor has come to see you. Suddenly, a black shape pushes them to the side and approaches your bedside, you reach for your sword but slowly realize who it is, [From.GetTitledFirstName], back from the forests of the druids!

On of the supplicants at your court today is hopping on one leg, trying to keep [From.GetHerHis] balance with the help of a knoted stick of wood. [From.GetSheHe] has a familiar look and as [From.GetSheHe] approaches your throne, you finally understand why, it is [From.GetTitledFirstName], back from the druids!
My child, what have the gods done to you?
[From.GetTitledFirstName] is back from the druidic groves, there he has learned much of the ways of the gods and our people, he has sung numerous stories and even come up with a few of his own.
I wish to hear of these new stories!

« My lord!, says own of your guards, a madman is dancing on the roof of the stables, we tried to get him down, but he just screams gibberish at us!» \n You follow your guards to the courtyard and soon understand that the madman is in fact,[From.GetTitledFirstName], struck mad by the gods.
We shall share this burden my child
[From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from the groves of the druids, but with a strange burden, a newborn child. While he refuses to talk of the mother, the childs wild eyes bode strange wisdom.
I will love him as my own.

Knowing of [From.GetTitledFirstName] impending return, you have prepared the most magnificent chambers for him. But, ever since his return, he has been spending his nights and days in the castle grove, delving more and more into the druidic lore, stopping only to speak of the wonders of the gods.
But what about the pleasures of life?

The secrets of the druids are many and earthly problems lose of their potency when confronted to those of the otherworld, thus [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned changed from his traning with the druids, he seems much more at peace and patient.
Father dies, Player Child is heir
This character is learning the secrets arts and rituals of the Druids, he has much to learn
A Druid is expected to follow the Celtic Virtues of honor, loyalty, hospitality, honesty, justice and courage. Gossip is starting to spread about your wicked habits.
Rome's military might has always relied upon highly disciplined and heavily armored infantry. This is where such soldiers are drilled.
column3: La puissance militaire de Rome a toujours compté sur une infanterie lourde et hautement disciplinée. C'est ici que de tels soldats sont entraînés.

column2: The Province of Cyrenaica et Creta
column3: Les Provinces de Cyrénaïque et de Crète

column2: The citizens of Cyrenaica et Creta can rejoice, as Roman law is once more upheld in this barren land. Yet another ancient Roman province has been returned to the bosom of the mightiest empire the civilised world has ever seen. May it never suffer the cruel touch of barbarians again.
column3: Les citoyens de Cyrénaïque et de Crète peuvent se réjouir, puisque la loi de Rome est une fois encore respectée sur ces terres stériles. Encore une province romaine de plus revient dans le sein du plus puissant empire que le monde civilisé ait connu. Que plus jamais il ne souffre aux prises des mains cruelles des barbares.

column2: Imperial rule over Sicilia, one of the last western outposts of the Empire to be lost to barbarian rule, has been reinstated yet again - this time hopefully for good.
column3: La loi impériale sur la Sicile, l'un des derniers avant postes de l'Empire à être perdu aux barbares, a été réinstauré à nouveau - cette fois pour de bon avec de la chance

column2: The Province of Corsica et Sardinia
column3: Les Provinces de Corse et de Sardaigne

column2: The islands of Corsica and Sardinia, originally inorporated in the empire after the First Pulic War, is yet again under imperial rule. The conquest of this strategic location in the Mediteranian heralds a glorious westward expansion of the Empire.
column3: Les îles de Corse et de Sardaigne, à l'origine incorporées dans l'empire après la Première Guerre Punique, est à nouveau sous contrôle impérial. La conquête de cet endroit stratégique en Méditerranée annonce une expansion glorieuse de l'Empire vers l'ouest.

column2: Viennensis, named after the town Vienne in southeastern Gaul, has long been lost to Roman rule, but has now been incorporated back into the Empire. It was originally formed as a merger of the provinces Gallia Aquitania and Gallia Narbonensis created by Caesar after his campaigns had expanded the old province of Gaul too far to be administered as a single province.
column3: La Viennoise, appelée ainsi d'après la ville de Vienne dans l'extrême sud-est de la Gaule, et longtemps écartée de Rome, est maintenant réincorporée dans l'Empire. Elle a été formée à l'origine lors de la fusion des provinces de Gallia Aquitania et Gallia Narbonensis crées par César après que ses campagnes aient étendu les frontières de la vieille Gaule trop loin pour être administrées en une seule province.

column2: If Rome, Constantinople, and other key territories of the old empire could be reclaimed, the Holy Roman Empire would win recognition in the eyes of the East as the true and rightful successor of the Roman State.
column3: Si Rome, Constantinople, et d'autre territoires clés de l'ancien empire pouvaient être récupérés, le Saint Empire Romain gagnerait la reconnaissance aux yeux de l'Est d'être le vrai et légitime successeur de l'État de Rome.

column2: If we were to hold all the core territories of the old empire, we could gain recognition as the true and rightful successor of the Roman State.
column3: Si nous possédions tous les territoires du coeur de le l'ancien empire, nous pourrions gagner la reconnaissance en tant que vrai et légitime successeur de l'Etat de Rome.

column2: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears! After the miraculous recovery of territory lost centuries ago, the Roman Empire has been reborn! Europe has endured dark times since the imperial frontiers were stormed by barbarians and province after province burned at their touch, but now a bright new age has dawned for all of civilization.\n\nThe Roman State will no longer be referred to as the "Empire of the Germans" by jealous pretenders in the East, but recognized as the true heir to the legacy of Rome. [Root.GetTitledFirstName] rules a restored Imperium Romanum, but much work remains to be done. There is still territory to recover and ancient borders to reclaim. For the Senate and People of Rome!
